channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Voter Fraud, Penalties Often Depend on Who’s Voting
item.description: Cases in Florida and a survey of prosecutions nationally indicate that despite the furor over voter fraud, prosecutions remain exceedingly rare and penalties vary wildly.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers in Riviera Beach, Fla., prepared ballots to be counted by machine after the November 2020 general election.

item.title: Democrats Fret as Stacey Abrams Struggles in Georgia Governor’s Race
item.description: She has been trailing her Republican rival, Gov. Brian Kemp, alarming Democrats who have celebrated her as the master strategist behind the state’s Democratic shift.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stacey Abrams has worked for years to register and turn out Democratic voters, helping to fuel victories by President Biden and two senators in the 2020 election cycle.

item.title: Trump Special Master Ruling Lifts Profile of Judge Aileen Cannon
item.description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon has issued the first highly scrutinized ruling of her short judicial career, involving the person who put her on the bench: former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon granted former President Donald J. Trump’s request to appoint a special master to review materials seized from Mar-a-Lago, his private Florida club.

item.title: Steve Bannon to Surrender to New York Authorities
item.description: After President Donald J. Trump pardoned him in a case connected to a crowd-funded border wall, the Manhattan district attorney’s office opened its own investigation.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, pardoned by former President Donald Trump in 2021, is turning himself in.

item.title: The Safe Space That Became a Viral Nightmare
item.description: An argument at Arizona State’s multicultural center spiraled into a disaster for everyone involved. Who was to blame?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Viren
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarra Tekola and Chase Beckerman, students at A.S.U. whose confrontation went viral.

item.title: Details Emerge About the Victims of the Mass Stabbing in Canada
item.description: All but one of the victims of the killings in the western province of Saskatchewan lived on an Indigenous reservation. One suspect remains on the run.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Darryl Burns with a photo of his sister, Gloria Burns, 61, who was among the victims of Sunday’s mass killing in Saskatchewan.

item.title: EU Leaders Say Putin’s Gas Power Is Weakening
item.description: In Germany and elsewhere, leaders are growing more confident that months of work to stockpile and line up alternate energy sources may help them blunt Russia’s weaponization of exports.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy, Erika Solomon and Anton Troianovski

item.title: Brooklyn Prosecutors Seek to Throw Out Scores of Convictions
item.description: The 378 cases — mostly low-level drug and traffic offenses — relied on the work of 13 police officers who were later convicted of crimes.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Gonzalez, right, the Brooklyn district attorney, in 2020.

item.title: Official Obama Portraits Are Finally Unveiled at the White House
item.description: In a break with tradition, there was no ceremony while former President Donald J. Trump held office. President Biden unveiled the Obama portraits: his by Robert McCurdy, hers by Sharon Sprung.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: After an unusual delay, the official White House portraits of former President Barack Obama and first lady Michelle Obama were unveiled Wednesday at a ceremony in the East Room.

item.title: Painting Michelle Obama Took 9 Months. Keeping it Secret Took 6 Years.
item.description: Sharon Sprung, an instructor at the Art Students League of New York, is a realist painter of the old school.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Sprung, who painted Michelle Obama’s official White House portrait, in her artist studio on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. What holds her interest is “the crinkle of an eye, the little noise of a lip.”

item.title: Apple Unveils New iPhone and Fitness Watch at Annual Event
item.description: For the first time in the pandemic, the company returned to Steve Jobs Theater to release its latest product updates.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Andrej Sokolow/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Steve Jobs Theater at Apple’s campus in Cupertino, Calif., on Wednesday. The company unveiled the iPhone 14, as well as new smartwatches and AirPods.

item.title: How China Has Added to Its Influence Over the iPhone
item.description: Apple is taking small steps toward India. But the production of its latest phone, set for introduction on Wednesday, shows how difficult it will be to make big changes.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Chinese engineers are playing a greater role in the creation of iPhones, even as Apple takes baby steps toward production outside the country.

item.title: China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Bind: No Easy Way Out Despite the Cost
item.description: From vaccines to propaganda, Beijing has prioritized politics over science, creating conditions that make it difficult for China to join other countries in adapting to life with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Wu Hao/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Covid testing in Chengdu, China, last week. The government locked down the 21 million residents of the city, one of country’s biggest and most economically important, this month.

item.title: Hochul Lifts Mask Mandate on N.Y.C. Public Transit
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul announced that face coverings must still be worn in health care facilities, including hospitals and nursing homes.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riders on public transit had already become lax about wearing masks before the governor’s announcement on Wednesday.

item.title: The Great U.S. Open Ball Debate of 2022
item.description: The Open is the only Grand Slam tournament where women use different balls than men, and the Wilson ‘regular-duty’ ball has gotten into some players’ heads.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tennis balls used by women at the U.S. Open have played faster than those used by the men.

item.title: The Late-Night Bike Races of the Central Park Raccoons
item.description: The Central Park Raccoons, a loose group of cyclists, gather after dark for impromptu races. Anything on two wheels (except electric bikes) can compete.
item.dc:creator: Michael Venutolo-Mantovani
item.media:credit: Emma Howells for The New York Times
item.media:description: The finish line at a recent late-night race in the bike lanes of Central Park.

item.title: How Michigan Resisted Far Right Extremism
item.description: Michigan may hold lessons for residents of other states looking to withstand the tide of authoritarianism and violence.
item.dc:creator: Barbara McQuade
item.media:credit: Seth Herald/Reuters
item.media:description: Militia members inside the Michigan State Capitol in 2020 protesting the extension of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's Covid emergency stay-at-home order.

item.title: The U.S. Has Led the War on Drugs Abroad for Decades, and It’s Been a Staggering Failure
item.description: The Biden administration’s new forward-thinking national policies are a step in the right direction, but the president must go further and end the global drug war.
item.dc:creator: Christy Thornton
item.media:credit: Ben Hickey

item.title: Is the Democratic Midterm Surge Overrated? Why Republicans Can Still Win the House and Senate.
item.description: The Dobbs ruling and falling gas prices may have shifted the narrative. But the G.O.P.’s chances in the midterms still look good.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Erick Erickson
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Couldn’t Have Done What He Did Without States Leading the Way
item.description: What is democracy? It depends on where you stand.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: Education in America: What Grown-Ups Don’t Understand About School
item.description: What is school really for? Students at Oakland’s Fremont High answer this question with their cameras.
item.dc:creator: Fremont High School students

item.title: With Malice Toward Quite a Few
item.description: When it comes to saving democracy, Joe Biden slumps to the occasion.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Why We Don’t Agree on High School Required Reading
item.description: Kaitlyn Greenidge and Esau McCaulley discuss why America’s schools can’t get on the same page about required reading lists.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Dmitry Marchenko/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: ‘Wellness’ Can Be a Trap for Moms. Here’s How to Avoid It.
item.description: Realizing that it’s not something you buy off the shelf.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: A Summer of Climate Disasters
item.description: Climate change has made extreme weather increasingly normal.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Bilawal Arbab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Flooding in northwestern Pakistan.

item.title: A Nuclear Power Plant on Ukraine’s Front Lines
item.description: Fighting at the Zaporizhzhia facility has become a critical flash point in the war, setting off a race to prevent disaster.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Luke Vander Ploeg, Nina Feldman, Will Reid, M.J. Davis Lin, Rachel Quester, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog, arriving at the Zaporizhzhia plant this month.

item.title: Chile’s Constitutional Fight Over Climate Change
item.description: Chileans rejected a proposed constitution that would have been the first to confront climate change. But they are not done.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Sura/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chileans voted to reject a new constitution on Sunday.

item.title: Breakfast With Grandma
item.description: A new New Yorker tucks into the West Village’s offerings with her Abueti, a longtime Manhattanite.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky
item.media:credit: Moriah Sawtelle
item.media:description: If you need a more portable breakfast, St. Jardim’s egg sandwich with smoked bacon, tomato jam and greens always satisfies.

item.title: Lawmakers Press Biden to Track U.S. Aid Tied to Civilian Harm in Yemen
item.description: Democrats and Republicans want the administration to do more to ensure that American military aid to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates does not contribute to civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yemenis dig graves for children killed when their bus was hit during a Saudi-led coalition airstrike in 2018.

item.title: From the U.S. to China, Major Economies Are Stalling. But Not India.
item.description: The Indian government expects growth to exceed 7 percent this year, though that pace may be hard to sustain as the global economy continues to slow.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: An electric scooter factory in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu last month.

item.title: From Boom to Gloom: Tech Recruiters Struggle to Find Work
item.description: As tech companies slow hiring and lay off workers, once-busy recruiters are shifting to other roles and cutting their rates.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: George Wylesol

item.title: Are Vasectomies Reversible?
item.description: If you are considering the procedure, but are worried about its permanence, here is what experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Why Is My Eyelid Twitching? Questions and Answers
item.description: And how do I get it to stop?
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Mark Elzey for The New York Times

item.title: What Should I Look for When Buying Whole Grains?
item.description: There are several reliable ways to identify whole-grain foods.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: iStock

item.title: Is the Saturated Fat in Chocolate as Bad as the Fat in Meat?
item.description: Chocolate contains a healthier blend of fats than meats do. But don’t go overboard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Are Calcium Supplements Safe?
item.description: Kidney stones are a known risk, but studies have investigated other potential safety concerns, including an increased risk of death, cancer and heart disease.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Matty Matheson, the Real Chef Who Doesn’t Play One on ”The Bear,” Launches a Clothing Line
item.description: The chef, who plays a handyman on “The Bear,” has launched Rosa Rugosa, a clothing line that fits him well.
item.dc:creator: Max Berlinger
item.media:credit: Brandon Watson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matty Matheson, who describes himself as a “fat, sweaty dude covered in tattoos,” has an empire that encompasses restaurants, cookbooks, YouTube shows, cookware and now a clothing line called Rosa Rugosa.
